Lecture: A structured presentation method where the trainer delivers content to learners, providing foundational knowledge and theoretical concepts essential for understanding the subject matter.
Demonstration: A hands-on method where the trainer shows learners how to perform specific tasks or procedures, allowing them to observe techniques before practicing independently.
Discussion: An interactive method that encourages learners to share ideas, ask questions, and engage in dialogue to deepen understanding and promote critical thinking.
Didactic Questioning: A guided questioning technique where the trainer poses questions to learners to stimulate thinking, check understanding, and encourage active participation in the learning process.
Practical Exercise: Hands-on activities where learners apply knowledge and skills in simulated or real-world scenarios to reinforce learning and build competency.
Case Study: Analysis of real-world scenarios or problems that allows learners to apply theoretical knowledge, develop problem-solving skills, and understand practical applications.
Role Play: A simulation technique where learners act out scenarios to practice interpersonal skills, decision-making, and handling of various situations in a safe environment.
Group Work: Collaborative activities where learners work together in teams to complete tasks, solve problems, and learn from each other's perspectives and experiences.
Self-directed Learning: A learner-centered approach where individuals take responsibility for their own learning, setting goals, identifying resources, and evaluating their progress.
E-Learning: Technology-based instruction delivered through digital platforms, allowing flexible, self-paced learning with multimedia content and interactive elements.
Project Work: Extended assignments where learners apply knowledge and skills to complete a substantial piece of work, demonstrating competency through practical application.
Workshop: Interactive sessions combining instruction with hands-on practice, allowing learners to immediately apply concepts and receive feedback in a collaborative environment.
Simulation: Recreated environments or scenarios that replicate real-world conditions, enabling learners to practice skills safely before applying them in actual situations.
Coaching: One-on-one guidance where a trainer provides personalized feedback, support, and direction to help learners develop specific skills and overcome challenges.
Mentoring: A developmental relationship where an experienced individual guides a less experienced learner, sharing knowledge, providing advice, and supporting professional growth.
Video-based Learning: Instruction delivered through recorded visual content, allowing learners to observe demonstrations, explanations, and examples at their own pace.
Reading Assignment: Self-study activities where learners review written materials to gain knowledge and prepare for discussions or practical applications.
Quiz/Assessment: Evaluation activities that measure learner understanding and retention of content, providing feedback on progress and identifying areas for improvement.
Brainstorming: A creative technique where learners generate ideas freely without initial criticism, fostering innovation and exploring multiple solutions to problems.
Peer Teaching: An approach where learners explain concepts to each other, reinforcing their own understanding while helping others learn.
